awd_titl_txt: Culturally Responsive Pedagogy in  Computer Science (CR in CS)
awd_abstract_narration:
In Fall 2017, New Mexico enacted legislation that will recognize one computer science course as satisfying a high school science or math graduation requirement, adopted CS standards in 2018, and allocated funding dedicated to CS PD, mainly supporting K-8 initiatives. With this new emphasis on CS education in NM, there is a critical need for NM HS CS teachers to enrich the experience of CS students from underserved communities. This project will establish a design-based implementation research partnership between the Computer Science Alliance, the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) New Mexico Chapter, and researchers from New Mexico State University and the National Indian Education Association. Together, the team will hold a series of convenings to co-design, gather feedback from stakeholders, and ultimately pilot a culturally responsive pedagogy-focused microcredential. With the long term goal of equitable and rigorous CS instruction for all students in New Mexico, especially students who identify as Hispanic and/or Native American, this partnership will support computer science teachers’ growth towards mastery of the CSTA Standards for CS Teachers, specifically focusing on increasing their use of culturally responsive and inclusive teaching practices. This project is jointly funded by the CSforAll:Research Practitioner Partnership program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This research- practitioner partnership (RPP), involving the leadership from the Computer Science Alliance, the Computer Science Teachers Association New Mexico Chapter, and researchers from New Mexico State University and the National Indian Education Association will support CS teachers’ growth towards mastery of the CSTA Standards for CS Teachers, focusing on increasing their use of culturally responsive and inclusive teaching practices. By leveraging the pre-existing relationships between all RPP members and their respective networks across NM, the project will convene stakeholders representing experienced and new CS teachers, equity-focused organizations, administrators/colleges of education, and industry leaders who will inform a culturally responsive pedagogy in CS microcredential tailored to the needs of Hispanic and Native American students in NM. The RPP will recruit a small group of teachers to experience pieces of a professional development sequence, use the strategies in their actual CS classrooms, and submit lesson plans in which exemplars will be archived for future dissemination.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The collaboration between Computer Science Alliance (CSA), New Mexico State University (NMSU), and National Indian Education Association (NIEA), via NSF Grant #2122559, developed a micro-credential process for enhancing Culturally Relevant Pedagogy in Computer Science (CRinCS). The CRinCS RPP team members created a meaningful and inclusive learning experience for CS teachers in NM Public Schools. Our approach to CS education recognizes and embraces multiple diverse backgrounds, experiences, and identities of K-12 educators and students with the intention of promoting academic success via social-cultural development for teachers. The CRinCS team sought to bridge the gap between students' cultural realities, teachers’ pedagogical practices, and the need for more CS learning needs in K-12 schooling.

The New Mexico CRinCS RPP team emphasized the importance of diversity and cultural perspectives in shaping how CS is taught and developed. The curriculum for the CS teachers in New Mexico included:

  1. Inclusive Curriculum: Culturally diverse examples, case studies, and projects related to the CS curriculum allowed teachers to see the relevance of computer science in their students’ lives and communities. This inclusive approach served to break stereotypes and encouraged CS teachers to engage with more perspectives related to CS curriculum. 

  2. Culturally Responsive Teaching Practices: NM CS teachers learned to employ additional  instructional strategies to more attentively include students' cultural backgrounds and experiences. CS teachers learned how to include culturally relevant activities, connect CS concepts to real-world issues affecting students’ communities, and create a classroom environment intended to value students’ perspectives.

  3. Collaborative and Cooperative Learning: The micro-credential process encouraged teachers to engage in their own collaborative projects and group work. These collaborations fostered a sense of community with each other and the program developers. These weekly interactions allowed the CS teachers to learn from each other's diverse experiences and knowledge from across NM. This collaborative approach supported a learning environment where teachers could collectively solve CS teaching challenges and develop their critical thinking skills.

  4. Authentic Assessments: The CRinCS curriculum supported assessment processes that included the diverse student population, skill sets, and knowledge. The CRinCS team emphasized the value of offering forms of assessment including: projects, presentations, and portfolios in ways that resonate with their students’ cultural backgrounds and strengths.

  5. Community Engagement: Within the diverse New Mexican schools, the value of connecting CS education with local communities, cultural organizations, and industry professionals was central to the CRinCS vision. The micro-credential provided CS teachers opportunities to examine the ways their CS education could be applied in their diverse teaching contexts. 

The CRinCS team was intentional about creating an inclusive and empowering learning environment which supported the professional development of teachers and prepared them to be more socially conscious/culturally competent CS educators.

 

The RPP team and the participants created a cohesive learning environment working together in managing new ideas to enhance culturally responsive actions in teaching CS. The excitement related to involvement from teachers and program directors was manifested in the high level of involvement and program completion of more than 80% of the initial enrollees completing the 35 hours of PD for the microcredential.  This high level of completion rate demonstrated a strong commitment to improving learning opportunities for New Mexico’s students and allowed one of the participating members from cohort 1 to create a second microcredential course with involvement from the CRinCS Team. 

 

Overall there were 82 participants that successfully completed the microcredential.  They had a wide range of experience in education as well as coming from diverse areas of our state.  We had a fairly representative group of the demographics of teachers in New Mexico with White and Latino/Hispanic making up about a third each of the participants. Most teachers were mid-career professionals having between 5 and 19 years experience.  There were 10 teachers that had less than 5 years of experience and 17 teachers with over  20 years experience. Most teachers were from the STEM, STEAM fields (science, math, STEAM).  Less than 10% were full time CS teachers (n=6). The districts where the teachers taught covered much of the state including 2 of the larger school districts.

Data collection was primarily through pre- and post-test surveys from a validated instrument as well as artifact analysis from shared lesson plans. Survey questions cover topics ranging from teacher mindset and curriculum design. The average increase for each participant from pre to post survey was 11 points per indicator.  Simply put, the average from the pre- and the post-survey demonstrated an increased score across all survey questions.

This CRinCS work was adapted by other groups to bring CRP in CS approaches to groups of educators that they work with.  Overall, the impacts of this project are still in the process of unfolding and will lead to a better CS experience for students in New Mexico and beyond.


 


Last Modified: 05/29/2024
Modified by: Paige Prescott
por.por_txt_cntn:
The collaboration between Computer Science Alliance (CSA), New Mexico State University (NMSU), and National Indian Education Association (NIEA), via NSF Grant #2122559, developed a micro-credential process for enhancing Culturally Relevant Pedagogy in Computer Science (CRinCS). The CRinCS RPP team members created a meaningful and inclusive learning experience for CS teachers in NM Public Schools. The CRinCS team sought to bridge the gap between students' cultural realities, teachers pedagogical practices, and the need for more CS learning needs in K-12 schooling.


The New Mexico CRinCS RPP team emphasized the importance of diversity and cultural perspectives in shaping how CS is taught and developed. The curriculum for the CS teachers in New Mexico included:




Inclusive Curriculum: Culturally diverse examples, case studies, and projects related to the CS curriculum allowed teachers to see the relevance of computer science in their students lives and communities. This inclusive approach served to break stereotypes and encouraged CS teachers to engage with more perspectives related to CS curriculum.




Culturally Responsive Teaching Practices: NM CS teachers learned to employ additional instructional strategies to more attentively include students' cultural backgrounds and experiences. CS teachers learned how to include culturally relevant activities, connect CS concepts to real-world issues affecting students communities, and create a classroom environment intended to value students perspectives.

These collaborations fostered a sense of community with each other and the program developers. These weekly interactions allowed the CS teachers to learn from each other's diverse experiences and knowledge from across NM. This collaborative approach supported a learning environment where teachers could collectively solve CS teaching challenges and develop their critical thinking skills.




Authentic Assessments: The CRinCS curriculum supported assessment processes that included the diverse student population, skill sets, and knowledge. The CRinCS team emphasized the value of offering forms of assessment including: projects, presentations, and portfolios in ways that resonate with their students cultural backgrounds and strengths.




Community Engagement: Within the diverse New Mexican schools, the value of connecting CS education with local communities, cultural organizations, and industry professionals was central to the CRinCS vision. The micro-credential provided CS teachers opportunities to examine the ways their CS education could be applied in their diverse teaching contexts.




The CRinCS team was intentional about creating an inclusive and empowering learning environment which supported the professional development of teachers and prepared them to be more socially conscious/culturally competent CS educators.





The RPP team and the participants created a cohesive learning environment working together in managing new ideas to enhance culturally responsive actions in teaching CS. The excitement related to involvement from teachers and program directors was manifested in the high level of involvement and program completion of more than 80% of the initial enrollees completing the 35 hours of PD for the microcredential. This high level of completion rate demonstrated a strong commitment to improving learning opportunities for New Mexicos students and allowed one of the participating members from cohort 1 to create a second microcredential course with involvement from the CRinCS Team.





Overall there were 82 participants that successfully completed the microcredential. They had a wide range of experience in education as well as coming from diverse areas of our state. We had a fairly representative group of the demographics of teachers in New Mexico with White and Latino/Hispanic making up about a third each of the participants. Most teachers were from the STEM, STEAM fields (science, math, STEAM). Less than 10% were full time CS teachers (n=6). The districts where the teachers taught covered much of the state including 2 of the larger school districts.


Data collection was primarily through pre- and post-test surveys from a validated instrument as well as artifact analysis from shared lesson plans. Survey questions cover topics ranging from teacher mindset and curriculum design. The average increase for each participant from pre to post survey was 11 points per indicator. Simply put, the average from the pre- and the post-survey demonstrated an increased score across all survey questions.


This CRinCS work was adapted by other groups to bring CRP in CS approaches to groups of educators that they work with. Overall, the impacts of this project are still in the process of unfolding and will lead to a better CS experience for students in New Mexico and beyond.
